title: 103_hr881
content: The Act is titled the "Ban on Smoking in Federal Buildings Act". It includes findings related to smoking in federal buildings. Congress finds that environmental tobacco smoke, originating from secondhand smoke exhaled by smokers and sidestream smoke from burning tobacco products, poses significant health risks to nonsmokers, including lung cancer and respiratory issues. With up to 90% of Americans spending their time indoors, exposure to this smoke in public buildings and indoor facilities is a concern, surpassing the risks of many EPA-regulated pollutants. The Administrator of General Services, with expertise in managing space for Federal employees, is qualified to regulate smoking in such spaces. SEC. 3. SMOKING PROHIBITION IN FEDERAL BUILDINGS. Smoking is prohibited in indoor areas of Federal buildings, with designated smoking areas allowed if ventilated separately and meeting specific criteria. The regulations prohibit smoking in indoor areas of Federal buildings, with designated smoking areas allowed if meeting specific criteria. The Administrator of General Services is responsible for enforcing the prohibition in Executive branch buildings. The regulations prohibit smoking in indoor areas of Federal buildings, with designated smoking areas allowed if meeting specific criteria. The Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts and the House Office Building Commission are responsible for enforcing the prohibition in judicial and legislative branch buildings, respectively. The regulations prohibit smoking in Federal buildings, with designated smoking areas allowed if meeting specific criteria. The House of Representatives, Senate, and other establishments in the legislative branch must enforce this prohibition in buildings they own or lease. The Architect of the Capitol is responsible for enforcing the prohibition in other legislative branch establishments. The regulations prohibit smoking in Federal buildings, with designated smoking areas allowed if meeting specific criteria. The House of Representatives, Senate, and other establishments in the legislative branch must enforce this prohibition in buildings they own or lease. The Architect of the Capitol is responsible for enforcing the prohibition in other legislative branch establishments, excluding the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Administrator of General Services must submit a report to Congress within 2 years of this Act's enactment, detailing compliance and research on ventilation methods. The Act does not override stricter state or local laws. For the purposes of this Act, definitions include Executive agency, Federal agency, Federal building, and military installation. The term "military installation" refers to facilities under the Department of Defense's jurisdiction, excluding those primarily used for civil works or flood control projects. Passed the House of Representatives on November 15, 1993.
